comment.author: 66041448@N00
comment._content:
Thanks for all the comments.  I made an artistic interpretation of the original photo using a method called smudge painting.  

The interpretation was executed using the smudge brush in Paint Shop Pro with a Wacom tablet and pressure sensitive stylus to apply digital smudge brush strokes to every pixel in the digital image.    

I also removed the tell-tale photograph glare from the iris and pupil of the eyes, to make it look more like a painting than a photograph.  Yes, and I fiddled with the whites of the eyes, with an intention to make them intense but retain enough depth so not to appear flat.

It took a couple of hours to make this painterly interpretation.

comment.author: 67803179@N00
comment._content: i love how one side of his hat is flipped up, and the other side of his collar is also flipped up. but my favorite part is the eyes. i think when you smooth out a photo like this and get rid of the wrinkles and freckles, you lose a part of what made this young guy who he was. the wrinkles around his eyes make him seem more human. maybe they were caused by sleepless nights awake worrying about his future. maybe the freckles were due to the many hours he spent out in the sun as a kid playing with his siblings. overall, a very raw and striking photograph.

comment.author: 47781571@N06
comment._content: Marvelous photo AND subject!  It amazes me that such a wonderful picture could come from the primitive equipment of the period. The young subject's determination and courage radiates, not only through the intensity of his pale, cool stare, but also from the fact that the photo shows no evidence of movement or falter! Nice contribution.
